jsx.http
Class Ajax

java.lang.Object
  js.Disposable
      jsx.Configurable
          jsx.Source
              jsx.http.Ajax

public final class Ajax
extends Source

Facilitates the administration of asynchronous HTTP connections and transmissions eliminating browser dependencies.

Note that, an Ajax object is an event source and therefore Configurable. An object of this class fires HTTP events of types extended from HTTPState. This class is quite intuitive and handy for creating Ajax applications in Java manner.

A use of this class involves three steps in a logical sense:

  1. Create an object of this class with the default constructor Ajax().
  2. Add necessary event listeners to the created object preparing to receive data from the JsXMLHttpRequest object obtained with its http() method.
  3. Call get(String, String, String), get(String), post(String, Object) or post(String, Object, String, String) to send request asynchronously.

Author:
J.J.Liu (Jianjun Liu) at http://www.jscripter.org
See Also:
Http

Ajax

The default constructor to create an Ajax object with the underlying asynchronous HTTP request created and high level event mechanism set up.

Method Detail

http

public final JsXMLHttpRequest http()

Gets the underlying HTTP request object.

Returns:
The underlying HTTP request object. This object is returned for retrieving its data properties only. Use the object with caution, not to break Ajax.
Since:
1.0

get

public final void get(java.lang.String url)

Opens the underlying HTTP request if it is not opened yet and sends an HTTP-GET to the specified URL through it.

Note that, this method returns immediately with nothing. Get the actual responses in the event listeners that should have been registered with the current event source object.

Parameters:
url - The URL that is the subject of the request. Most browsers impose a same-origin security policy and require that this URL have the same host name and port as the document that contains the script. Relative URLs are resolved in the normal way, using the URL of the document that contains the script.
Since:
1.0

get

public final void get(java.lang.String url,
                      java.lang.String username,
                      java.lang.String password)

Opens the underlying HTTP request if it is not opened yet and sends an HTTP-GET to the specified URL through it with explicit credentials.

Note that, this method returns immediately with nothing. Get the actual responses in the event listeners that should have been registered with the current event source object.

Parameters:
url - The URL that is the subject of the request. Most browsers impose a same-origin security policy and require that this URL have the same host name and port as the document that contains the script. Relative URLs are resolved in the normal way, using the URL of the document that contains the script.
username - An optional argument specifying authorization user name for use with URLs that require authorization. If specified, it overrides the user name specified in the URL itself.
password - An optional argument specifying authorization password for use with URLs that require authorization. If specified, it overrides the password specified in the URL itself.
Since:
1.0

post

public final void post(java.lang.String url,
                       java.lang.Object body)

Opens the underlying HTTP request if it is not opened yet and sends an HTTP-POST to the specified URL through it.

Note that, this method returns immediately with nothing. Get the actual responses in the event listeners that should have been registered with the current event source object.

Parameters:
url - The URL that is the subject of the request. Most browsers impose a same-origin security policy and require that this URL have the same host name and port as the document that contains the script. Relative URLs are resolved in the normal way, using the URL of the document that contains the script.
body - Specifies the body of the POST request, as a string or JsDocument object.
Since:
1.0

abort

public final void abort()

Cancels the underlying HTTP request of the current Ajax object, closing connections and stopping any pending network activity.

This method resets the JsXMLHttpRequest object to a JsXMLHttpRequest.readyState of JsXMLHttpRequest.UNINITIALIZED and aborts any pending network activity. You might call this method, for example, if a request has taken too long, and the response is no longer necessary.

This method fires an HTTPAborted event from the current Ajax object if the underlying HTTP request had been open but not loaded and has had to be aborted.

Since:
1.0
See Also:
Http.abort(JsXMLHttpRequest), JsXMLHttpRequest.abort()

setTimeout

public static final void setTimeout(Ajax ajax,
                                    java.lang.Number ms)

Sets a timeout in milliseconds to the current Ajax object so that it will be aborted and fire an HTTPAborted event when its underlying HTTP request has been waited for a longer time than the specified limit.

Setting a timeout of null or 0 means no limitation. The previous timeout can be canceled by call this method again with a timeout of null or 0.

Parameters:
ajax - The current Ajax object.
ms - Timeout limit in milliseconds.
Since:
1.0

unwrap

protected final Ajax unwrap()

Returns the wrapped event source.

The event queuing and dispatching mechanism in the superclass tries to dispatch an event fired from an event source also to its wrapped source by calling this method, if this object does wrap another valid source.

An Ajax object wraps nothing and this method simply returns null to make the high level event mechanism work.

Specified by:
unwrap in class Source
Returns:
null.
Since:
1.0

getParent

protected final Source getParent()

Returns the container source object if this one is graphically contained by another graphical event source.

The event queuing and dispatching mechanism of the superclass tries to dispatch an event fired from an event source also to its container by calling this method, if this source is graphically contained by another valid source and the event wants to bubble, that is, its Source.Event.BUBBLE configurable property is true.

An Ajax object is neither graphical nor containable and this method simply returns null to make the high level event mechanism work.

Specified by:
getParent in class Source
Returns:
null.
Since:
1.0
